life_satisfaction.definition: Measures general satisfaction with life and living conditions
examples: I'm content with how things are going
I'm happy with my living situation
I'm pleased with where I am
items: I am satisfied with my life
Taking everything into consideration, during the past week how satisfied have you been with your living/household situation
How would you rate your overall life satisfaction and contentment during the past week
Taking everything into consideration, during the past week how satisfied have you been with your overall sense of well being
In most ways my life is close to my ideal
The conditions of my life are excellent
item_references: Q-LES-Q-SF (Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire)_11
Q-LES-Q-SF (Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire)_16
Q-LES-Q-SF (Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire)_14

eudaimonic_well_being.definition: Measures meaning of life, purpose, values, self-acceptance, and sense of life having richness and significance
examples: I know what's important to me
I have a sense of purpose
My life feels rich and full
I'm living according to my values
I feel more enthusiastic about life
items: Your life has more richness
Your life has more meaning
The experience has changed your philosophy of life positively
Your sense of values (i.e., what is important to you in life) has changed positively
You are a more authentic person
You have more enthusiasm for life in general
Your appreciation for life has increased
I have a greater appreciation for the value of my own life

social_well_being.definition: Measures quality of social relationships, interpersonal connections, and sense of belonging
examples: I'm satisfied with my social life
I feel close to my family
I'm more sensitive to others' needs
I care more about helping people
items: You have a more positive relationship with others
Taking everything into consideration, during the past week how satisfied have you been with your social relationships
Taking everything into consideration, during the past week how satisfied have you been with your family relationships
You have become more sensitive to the needs of others
You have greater interpersonal perceptiveness (i.e., sensitivity)
You now feel a greater need for service for others
Your social concern/compassion has increased
item_references: Q-LES-Q-SF (Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire)_5
Q-LES-Q-SF (Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire)_6

spiritual_well_being.definition: Measures spiritual experiences, sense of connection to something greater
examples: I experience a sense of the sacred
items: You have more inner peace (i.e. centeredness, serenity, calmness)
I experienced profound inner peace

calm.definition: the state of being peaceful, composed, and free from agitation, worry, or anger
items: Feelings of peace and tranquillity
I have felt calm and relaxed
I've been feeling relaxed
I feel calm

resilience.definition: Measures ability to cope with difficulties, bounce back from adversity, and adapt to challenges
examples: I can get through tough times

optimism.definition: Measures optimistic outlook, positive expectations, and hopeful thinking
examples: I expect good things to happen
items: You have more optimism
I've been feeling optimistic about the future

openness.definition: Measures openness to new experiences, imagination, creativity, intellectual curiosity, and appreciation for variety
examples: I like to try new things
items: If I wish I can imagine things so vividly that it's like watching a good movie or hearing a good story
My imagination was extremely vivid
Has a good, active imagination
You are a more creative person
Is creative and inventive
Is original, comes up with new ideas

conscientiousness.definition: Measures organization, attention to detail, carefulness, thoroughness, and self-discipline in actions
items: Does things quickly and carefully
Does things carefully and completely

extraversion.definition: Measures sociability, assertiveness, and preference for social interaction

agreeableness.definition: Measures cooperation, trust, kindness, tolerance, and concern for others
items: You have more patience/ability to tolerate frustration
You are more tolerant toward others

experiential_avoidance.definition: Measures avoidance of difficult emotions, challenging experiences, fear, and tendency to escape uncomfortable states
examples: I was afraid it wouldn't end
I tried to make it stop
I wanted to escape the feeling
I need this to go away
I'm scared this will last forever
I want out of this state
items: I was afraid that the state I was in would last forever

surrender.definition: Measures capacity to surrender, let go of control, and release resistance
examples: I'm ready to accept what comes
I don't need to fight this
I can just be with this
items_simplified: ready to accept what is to come
ready to receive whatever is ahead
items: I've stopped resisting and released control
I now have to let go of resistance
I now know I don't have to keep struggling
I am now ready to accept what is to come
I have now ceased straining
I am now ready to receive whatever is ahead, even if difficult
I now feel able to listen without fighting back
I have now let go of compulsion and thinking

acceptance.definition: Measures capacity to accept present thoughts, feelings, experiences, and circumstances
examples: I'm okay with how I feel
I don't need to change this
It's okay to feel this way

absorption_flow.definition: Measures capacity for deep absorption in experiences and flow states
examples: I lost myself in the experience

emotional_breakthrough.definition: Measures emotional breakthrough experiences, cathartic release, and resolution of emotional issues
examples: I finally let it all out
I resolved something I'd been holding

spirituality_mystical.definition: Measures spiritual experiences, mystical-type experiences, and transcendent states
examples: I was connected to all things
items_simplified: certainty of encounter with ultimate reality
items: You are convinced now, as you look back on your experience, that in it you encountered ultimate reality
Certainty of encounter with ultimate reality (in the sense of being able to 'know' and 'see' what is really real)
Experience of unity with ultimate reality
I think I really know what some people mean when they talk about mystical experiences
Experience of oneness or unity with the objects and/or persons perceived in your surroundings
Experience of oneness in relation to an "inner world" within
I felt one with my surroundings
I had the sense of being connected to everything

insight.definition: Measures psychological insight, self-understanding, and gaining new perspectives
examples: I became aware of patterns I ignored
I see my life in a new way
items: I have become more conscious of aspects of my lifestyle that I used to ignore or not be fully aware of
I have become more conscious of aspects of my 'self' that I used to ignore or not be fully aware of
I have become more conscious of aspects of my past that I used to ignore or not be fully aware of

cognitive_flexibility.definition: Measures ability to shift thinking patterns, mental flexibility, and adaptability in thought processes
examples: I can see things from different angles
I'm open to changing my mind
I'm not stuck in one way of thinking

post_traumatic_growth.definition: Measures positive psychological change following adversity or challenging experiences
examples: I'm stronger from what I went through
I found meaning in my hardship
I appreciate life more after what happened
I'm a better person because of it
That difficult experience helped me grow
I discovered strengths I didn't know I had
I feel sad all the time
items_simplified: feel sad less than half time
feel sad more than half time
items: Feelings of depression have increased
Sadness
Is sad, depressed
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless
I feel sad less than half the time
I feel sad nearly all of the time
I feel sad more than half the time

anxiety.definition: Anxiety is a feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease, often about an imminent event or something with an uncertain outcome. We include anxiety disorders
items: Feelings of anxiety have increased
Trouble relaxing

anhedonia.definition: The loss of capacity or failure to experience pleasure. The lack of motivation and apathy
items_simplified: interest in only one or two activities
items: I have virtually no interest in formerly pursued activities
I notice that I am less interested in people or activities
I find I have interest in only one or two of my formerly pursued activities

low_energy_fatigue.definition: Fatigue is a state of extreme tiredness and reduced energy, mental or physical, often resulting from exertion, lack of sleep, stress, or illness.
items: My thoughts and actions were slowed down
I find that my thinking is slowed down or my voice sounds dull or flat
I get tired more easily than usual
I really cannot carry out most of my usual daily activities because I just don't have the energy

guilt.definition: Guilt involves a focus on a specific behavior that is negatively evaluated
examples: wish I could take it back
items: Persistent self-accusations, or definite but still rational ideas of guilt or sin or increasingly pessimistic about the future
Delusions of ruin, remorse or unredeemable sin or self-accusations which are absurd and unshakable

concentration_issues.definition: Measures problems with concentration, cognitive focus, attention, and decision-making
examples: I can't read or follow conversations
items: Difficulties in concentrating and sustaining thought which reduces ability to read or hold a conversation
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television
I cannot concentrate well enough to read or cannot make even minor decisions
Most of the time, I struggle to focus my attention or to make decisions
I feel indecisive
I occasionally feel indecisive or find that my attention wanders

worry.definition: Measures worry and inability to control worrying thoughts
examples: I keep thinking about what could go wrong

rumination.definition: Self-focused thoughts on negative mood and the possible causes and consequences of that mood (Brinker and Dozois). Ruminative flooding: uncontrolled and racing thoughts and somatic symptoms of headache and pressure in the head (Galynker et al, 2017)

sleep_issues.definition: Sleep issues, also known as sleep disorders, refer to conditions that disrupt normal sleep patterns. These issues can involve problems falling asleep, staying asleep, or experiencing restful sleep. Common examples include insomnia, sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, and narcolepsy.
items_simplified: awaken 1 hour early, can't go back to sleep
awaken 1 hour early, go back to sleep
items: I sleep longer than 12 hours in a 24-hour period including naps
I sleep no longer than 12 hours in a 24-hour period including naps
I sleep no longer than 10 hours in a 24-hour period including naps
Sleep reduced or broken by at least two hours
Less than two or three hours sleep
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much
Slight difficulty dropping off to sleep or slightly reduced, light or fitful sleep
I awaken at least 1 hour before I need to, and can't go back to sleep
I almost always awaken at least 1 hour or so before I need to, but I go back to sleep eventually
More than half the time, I awaken more than 30 minutes before I need to get up
I have a restless, light sleep with a few brief awakenings each night

appetite_eating_weight.definition: Measures appetite changes, eating behaviors, food intake patterns, and weight changes
items: I eat much less than usual and only with personal effort
I eat somewhat less often or lesser amounts of food than usual
I rarely eat within a 24-hour period, and only with extreme personal effort or when others persuade me to eat
I regularly eat more often and/or greater amounts of food than usual
I feel a need to eat more frequently than usual
Poor appetite or overeating
Slightly reduced appetite
No appetite or food is tasteless
I feel driven to overeat both at mealtime and between meals
I have lost 5 pounds or more
I have lost 2 pounds or more
I have gained 2 pounds or more
I have gained 5 pounds or more
I feel as if I've had a slight weight loss
I feel as if I've had a slight weight gain
I have not had a change in my weight

suicidal_ideation.definition: Measures thoughts of death, suicide, self-harm, and suicidal behaviors
items_simplified: think of suicide several times a day
think of suicide several times a week
items: I think of suicide or death several times a day in some detail, or I have made specific plans for suicide or have actually tried to take my life
I think of suicide or death several times a week for several minutes
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself

agitation_restlessness.definition: Agitation is a state of mental and/or physiological restlessness. It can either be of entirely mental nature and thereby be non-observable from the outside or it can be accompanied by a physiological component that involves aimless behaviors or fidgety movements on a low-grade organizational level like pacing or jittering
items: Being so restless that it is hard to sit still
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual
I'm often fidgety, wringing my hands, or need to shift how I am sitting
I have impulses to move about and am quite restless
At times, I am unable to stay seated and need to pace around

irritability.definition: Aggression is behavior intended to harm or intimidate others. It can be physical or verbal, manifesting as threats, assaults, or hostile actions.  Irritability: a proneness to experience negative affective states, such as anger, annoyance, and frustration upon little provocation, and may be outwardly expressed in the form of aggressive behavior.
items: Your negative expression of anger (e.g. ridicule, outward expression of irritability toward others) has increased
I often get angry at the way people treat me
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable

somatic_symptoms.definition: Measures physical symptoms associated with psychological distress
examples: My body is reacting to stress

self_confidence.definition: Measures self-confidence and sense of personal agency
items: Your self-confidence/self-assurance has increased
I've been feeling confident
I feel self confident

positive_behavioral_change.definition: Measures positive changes in behavior and life conduct
examples: I'm taking better care of myself
items: Your behavior has changed in ways you would consider positive since the experience
Self-described behavioral changes (ie, quitting smoking)

humor_playfulness.definition: Measures capacity for humor, playfulness, and lighthearted approach to life
examples: I have a sense of humor about things
I don't take everything so seriously
items: You have more good-natured humor/playfulness/lightness of being

music.definition: Measures how music influence overall experience
examples: The music led me through different phases
It felt like the music was communicating with me
I realized the music reflected my mind
I became one with the music
The music took me on a journey
items: Were there any aspects in the music that influenced your experience in a positive way
Were there any aspects in the music that influenced your experience in a negative way
Did the music influence your experience and if so in what ways
Can you comment on how the different styles of music influenced your experience and which music did you prefer

interest_engagement.definition: Measures level of interest in activities, people, and surroundings
examples: I want to try new things
items: I've been feeling interested in other people
I've been interested in new things

lonely_isolated.definition: Loneliness: aversive state experienced when a discrepancy exists between the interpersonal relationships one wishes to have and those that one perceives they currently have. The perception that one's social relationships are not living up to some expectation (Heinrich & Gullone 2006). Isolation: the expression of solitary behavior that results from peer rejection (Rubin & Burgess). Related to thwarted belongingness where the person perceives loneliness, isolation, and a failing to meet one's need to belong (Van Orden et al 2010)
examples: no one I can talk to
items: Isolation and loneliness
Feeling of isolation from people and things
I felt isolated from everything and everyone

negative_relationship_types_processes.definition: Mention of potentially negative relationship types (widow, my ex) and processes (divorce, ghosting)

kinship.definition: Types of family, friends, and other key social relationships

being_bullied.definition: Bullying is defined as intentional, repeated, and harmful aggressive behavior (verbal, physical, social) often with an imbalance of power between the perpetrators and the victims
examples: try to make me feel bad

sexual_abuse_harassment.definition: Any non-consensual act or behavior of a sexual nature imposed on someone. It can range from unwanted sexual touching and coercion to rape and exploitation. We also include sexual harassment in this lexicon.

physical_violence.definition: acts of physical force intended to hurt, damage, or kill someone or something. It's a broader term that can encompass abuse, assault, and other forms of harmful physical contact

alcohol_use_behavior.definition: Mentions of types of alcohol beverages and related behaviors (drinking), measures (shot), and states (drunk)

substance_use_behavior.definition: Mentions of types of abused substances and related behaviors (snort), measures (8 ball), and states (high, buzz)

impulsive.definition: A predisposition toward rapid, unplanned reactions to internal or external stimuli without regard to the negative consequences of these reactions to the impulsive individuals or to others

defeated_feeling_like_a_failure.definition: The perception of a failed struggle, feelings of powerlessness and a sense of losing social status or missing personal goals
items: Feeling bad about yourself or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down
Fluctuating ideas of failure, self-reproach or self depreciation

feeling_like_a_burden.definition: Misperceptions of being a burden on close others and is characterized by self-hatred as well as a belief that one is a liability for others.
examples: difficult for me to ask for help
feel guilty about others caring for me

shame_self-disgust_worthlessness.definition: Self-disgust: the basic emotion of disgust becomes directed at a core and stable feature of the self (Clarke et al 2019). Shame: the entire self that is painfully scrutinized and negatively evaluated, considering oneself a bad person (Tangney). Worthlessness: often measured through low self esteem (ex Horvath & morf). self criticism: "tendency to ruminate on feelings of inadequacy and personal failure" (Coyne & whiffen)
examples: I don't deserve to be here
items: Sometimes I feel completely worthless
I often feel inferior to others

panic_panic_attacks.definition: Panic attack: An abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes and during which time four or more of the following symptoms occur: palpitations, pounding heart or accelerated heart rate, sweating, trembling or shaking, sensations of shortness of breath or smothering, feeling of choking, chest pain or discomfort, nausea or abdominal distress, feeling dizzy, unsteady, lightheaded, or faint, derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (being detached from oneself), fear of losing control or going crazy, fear of dying, paresthesias (numbness or tingling sensation), chills or hot flushes
items: Panic
Unrelenting dread or anguish or overwhelming panic

entrapment_desire_to_escape.definition: Entrapment: desire to escape from an unbearable situation tied with the perception that all escape routes are blocked (Gilbert & Allan, 1998). Desire to escape: wish to escape from awareness of current life problems their implications about the self (Baumeister, 1990)

trauma_post-traumatic_stress_disorder.definition: Psychological trauma is a type of damage to the mind that occurs as a result of a distressing event. It is often the result of an overwhelming amount of stress that exceeds one's ability to cope or integrate the emotions involved with that experience. Trauma can result from an event, series of events, or set of circumstances that is experienced by an individual as physically or emotionally harmful or life-threatening and that has lasting adverse effects on the individual's functioning and mental, physical, social, emotional, or spiritual well-being. Post-traumatic stress disorder: "an event or events that involve actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of self and others and the person's response involved intense fear, helplessness, or horror" with a diagnosis including either re-experiencing the traumatic event, avoidance and numbing, and increased arousal

emotional_pain.definition: Feelings of mental pain, hurt, anguish, soreness, aching, psychological pain in the mind
items: Emotional and/or physical suffering

grief_bereavement.definition: Sadness from losing a loved one (grief) which may result in depressive symptoms (bereavement). This may also include losing a relationship or the health of a loved one.
items: Feelings of grief

lack_of_meaning_or_life_purpose.definition: One's life lacks meaning, does not make sense, does not have purpose, or is insignificant
items: I feel that life is empty or wonder if it's worth living

emptiness.definition: The experience of profound hollowness and feelings of absence from one's own life.
items: I feel that life is empty or wonder if it's worth living
I experienced unbearable emptiness

hopeless.definition: Generalized negative expectations of the future (McMillan 2007)
items: Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless

perfectionism.definition: Self-oriented perfectionism refers to setting high personal standards and experiencing feelings of distress if failing to meet desired standards. Other-oriented perfectionism refers to having high expectations of others. Socially prescribed perfectionism refers to the expectations and beliefs that others expect perfectionism in one's performance
examples: be perfect in everything I do

psychosis_schizophrenia.definition: Psychosis: A mental health condition characterized by a disconnection from reality, often involving hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren't there) and delusions (strongly held false beliefs). Schizophrenia: A chronic and severe mental disorder that affects how a person thinks, feels, and behaves, often marked by symptoms like psychosis (which involves hallucinations, delusions), but also disordered thinking, and impaired social functioning

mania_bipolar_disorder.definition: Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition that is marked by significant mood swings, which include periods of intense emotional highs, known as mania or hypomania, and lows, known as depression. During manic phases, individuals may feel overly happy and energetic or irritable, often with a decreased need for sleep and an increase in activity or impulsive behaviors. During depressive phases, individuals may feel sad, indifferent, or hopeless, with a lack of energy and difficulty in enjoying activities they once found pleasurable.

eating_disorders_related_behaviors.definition: Eating disorders are mental health conditions characterized by unhealthy and obsessive behaviors related to food, eating, and body image. Common types include anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge-eating disorder

physical_health_symptoms_disorders.definition: Physical health issues refer to any condition or disorder that affects the body's normal functioning. These can range from acute illnesses like infections to chronic diseases such as diabetes or heart conditions as well as psychosomatic conditions.  Physical disability: physical impairments, functional limitations, and social activity restrictions stemming from the disability

gender_sexual_identity.definition: Gender identity refers to an individual's sense of their self as male, female, transgender, non-binary, genderfluid, agender, or something else. Gender identity is distinct from the cultural roles, behaviors, and attributes expected of women and men based on their sex assigned at birth. Sexual identity, also known as sexual orientation, refers to the pattern of romantic or sexual attraction to others. Common sexual identities include: heterosexual, homosexual, bisexual, pansexual, and asexual
examples: women who have sex with women

discrimination.definition: Discrimination is the unjust or prejudicial treatment of different categories of people, often based on characteristics like race, age, sex, ethnicity, nationality, gender, sexual orientation or disability. It involves actions or attitudes that disadvantage or harm individuals or groups, and can occur in various settings such as the workplace, education, or public services

financial_problems.definition: Problems related to managing money, earning a living, employment, or business activities, involving budgeting, spending, and investing

barriers_to_psychological_treatment.definition: Sociodemographic characteristics of the client impacting his or her ability to receive treatment
examples: deal with it on my own
don't want to go to the hospital

treatment.definition: Forms of commonly pursued pharmacological, psychotherapeutic, and behavioral mental health treatments

excited.definition: Measures feelings of excitement, enthusiasm, and energetic arousal

angry.definition: Measures feelings of anger, irritation, and hostile affect

afraid.definition: Measures feelings of fear, apprehension, and fearful affect
examples: I'm worried something bad will happen

proud.definition: Measures feelings of pride, self-worth, and positive self-regard
examples: I'm satisfied with what I've done

alert.definition: Measures feelings of alertness, attentiveness, and wakeful awareness

hallucination.definition: Measures hallucinations, including visual and auditory perceptions of things that are not present in external reality. Visual hallucinations may include seeing patterns, shapes, colors, or entities that don't exist, while auditory hallucinations involve hearing sounds, voices, or music that aren't there.
examples: I saw things that were not there
I saw patterns on the walls
I saw colors and shapes that weren't real
I heard music that wasn't playing
Things were moving that shouldn't be
The visuals were unlike anything I've ever seen

belief_delusions.definition: Measures unusual or false beliefs and delusional thinking, including beliefs about special powers, messages from the universe, paranoid thoughts, or convictions that feel profoundly true but may not align with consensus reality.
belief_delusions.dimension_category: Taxonomy of Altered States (Cardena et al., 2025)
examples: I thought I had special powers
I believed the universe was sending me messages
I was convinced I could read minds
I thought people were plotting against me
I believed I had discovered the meaning of everything
I was certain I was being watched
I thought I could control things with my mind
I believed I was communicating with entities
I was convinced this was more real than reality
I thought I had unlocked secret knowledge

out_of_body_experience.definition: Measures out-of-body experiences where one perceives themselves as separate from or outside their physical body, including sensations of floating, viewing oneself from an external perspective, or feeling disembodied.
out_of_body_experience.dimension_category: Taxonomy of Altered States (Cardena et al., 2025)
examples: I felt like I left my body
I could see myself from outside
I felt separated from my physical body
I was looking down at my body
I was hovering above the room
My consciousness felt separate from my body
I observed myself from a distance

ego_dissolution.definition: Measures the dissolution or loss of the sense of self and ego boundaries, including experiences of self-transcendence, loss of personal identity, merging with the environment, and the temporary dissolution of the distinction between self and other.
ego_dissolution.dimension_category: Taxonomy of Altered States (Cardena et al., 2025)
examples: I lost my sense of self
The boundaries between me and everything else disappeared
I merged with everything around me
I had no sense of being a separate person
